rss.title: Tetragrammaton
rss.subtitle: God's name never sounded so cool.

subtitle_detail.value: God's name never sounded so cool.

transcription.full_transcript: Welcome to Catholic Stuff You Should Know, a J-10 initiative. Welcome to the podcast. Hey, welcome to Catholic Stuff You Should Know. This is Deacon Mike. This is John. It's been about three weeks now since Christmas. You're still wearing the Christmas sweater. What's going on with that? Well, my sister gave it to me. I usually wear some really messed up fashion, and she wanted me to be a little bit... with it this Christmas. So here I am in Argyle. I guess Argyle is in. It's better than the old coat you were wearing that you spilled wine on. It looked like somebody stabbed you in the chest. It was like blood all over. Oh, I also got a black flannel. Black flannel. Very nice. Fleece? Flannel? No, fleece. I think they're called fleeces, yeah. Flannels are what they wear up in the north, up in Wisconsin. Anyways, what are we talking about today? Both are warm. Today we talk about the Tetragrammaton. Tetragrammaton. That sounds like the name of the... calculator I owned in high school, or the name of the villain from Transformers. What did they call those? TI-90s or something? Yeah, 83 plus. That's what I thought. Oh, yeah. That's pretty sweet. Now, the Tetragrammaton is actually a technical biblical scholarship term. Oh, fancy. It's a term from the Old Testament scholarship that refers to the name of God in the Old Testament. Okay. So you're going to find four letters. Tetra is four. Grammaton is writing or letters. So you're going to find four letters in the Old Testament scriptures that were originally written in Hebrew that do not have any vowels. So they can't be pronounced, and they are never pronounced the way they're written. Everything else is read just like normal. But with the Tetragrammaton, the name of God. You have four letters that are not pronounced. So the Tetragrammaton is a technical name for the name of God in the Hebrew because it's unpronounceable, because it's only four consonants. And we don't know how to pronounce it because there's no vowels. Exactly. Both we don't know how to pronounce it since really the fall of the temple. We can speculate, but they haven't been using it. since the fall of the temple in 70 AD, but also out of respect, out of deference and reverence for the name of God, which is very, very sacred to Jews. And the Tetragrammaton is usually pronounced Adonai, which would be written very differently, but means Lord. Another option would be to use the term Hashem. Hashem, okay. Now this brings me to a point. Several months ago I was walking through one of the Orthodox Jewish neighborhoods in town, and I saw this guy on the Sabbath walking, and I wanted to be like, hey, it's like a brother of Abraham. So I said Baruch Hashem to him, and he looked totally freaked out. Did I offend him? What did I say? I think we're going to have to find a rabbi and find out what you I think probably poor pronunciation offended him. That was what it was. And I don't really look Jewish. It's the blonde hair, I guess. No facial hair. Right. He might be confused. He's expecting you worship Jesus. And here you are blessing Hashem, the name. There you go. Now, Mike, I got a couple questions for you about the Old Testament. Now, the Old Testament was originally written in Hebrew. Now, I have been told that the whole Old Testament in the Hebrew had no vowels. And so the only way that it could be read was It had to be handed on orally. There had to be an oral transmission and a tradition along with the written Hebrew text. Is that true? That is true. That's pretty interesting. That is true. The vowels were inserted during the... The later half of the last millennium. So they're kind of a recent addition. What we have now is called a Masoretic text, which kind of carries that tradition, has put the tradition that came down from the ages into written forms and pointing for vowel system. But even this Masoretic text, when it gets to the name of God, it just leaves it. It's unpronounceable. No vowels. It's tetragrammaton. It's protected, that tetragrammaton. Tetragrammaton. Okay. Four letters. Letters that are protected, absolutely protected. Now, that begs the question, how do we know what it means? Or what does it mean? Is it just a word that doesn't have any expression? No. We also have a Greek text that's very, very old that was a translation of the Hebrew text. So the Old Testament was originally written in Hebrew and it was translated into the Greek? Yeah. We've got a text called the Septuagint. Septuagint. It was written between the 3rd and 1st centuries BC in Alexandria, Egypt. Okay. And there they spoke Greek, and the people had a hard time understanding Hebrew anymore, but they wanted to read the scriptures. They were Jews, and they wanted to read the scriptures. So they had a translation made by 70 elders, so goes the legend, into Greek. And in that translation, The Tetragrammaton, the four-letter name of God, was translated into words, ego eimi, which means I am. So that's the first translation we have of the Tetragrammaton. Exactly. The name of God, it gets translated into ego eimi, which is I am, which is what we see reflected in the English. Is that correct? Right. Okay. Right. If you pick up a Bible, you'll often find that the Tetragrammaton, the name, the sacred name, translated as I am. Kind of small caps type thing. Right, which is a possibility. With the four letters in the Tetragrammaton, Yod, He, Vav, and He, they could form the word Yahweh, which means I am. So that's kind of the modern rendering of the Tetragrammaton. We pronounce it as Yahweh. Perfect. Okay, now, but I had heard recently that the Vatican came out, I think it's the Congregation for Divine Worship, said, no more Yahweh. No more of this Yahweh, I know you are near, or whatever these cheesy 70s songs. Exactly. That's got to go. That's what they're saying. Why would they say that? Yeah, it's out. You know why? Because of the reverence that the Jewish people have for the name. Catholics are trying to be mindful of that reverence and careful with the name. Any questions, concerns, thoughts, CatholicStuffPodcast at gmail.com. Send us an email. Let us know what you're thinking. And we'll see you next week. All right.

summarization.results: The Tetragrammaton is the unpronounceable sacred name of God in Hebrew, consisting of four consonants without vowels. It has not been pronounced since 70 AD, and alternative pronunciations like Adonai or Hashem are used out of respect. The Old Testament was originally written in Hebrew without vowels, and the Tetragrammaton remains unpronounced and protected, with the modern rendering being "Yahweh."
